During the 1848 election, his opponent William Henry Harrison ran an ad with the headline, "The Bloody Career of General Taylor." They ran a fiery campaign, filled with political attacks against the Whig Party and its president Millard Fillmore. The 1852 campaign resulted in the election of Democrat Franklin Pierce. In this election, the slogan was "Fillmore, or Blood."  The Democratic Party used this slogan in the 1860 presidential election too, to persuade voters to vote for Abraham Lincoln. The slogan may have caused a mild panic. "Spoils" or the goods won by victorious political candidates were thought to be bloodied, and Taylor's death was on the minds of many voters. Lincoln won the presidency, but was then assassinated in the White House."
